Directly we saw the boat making after us--when I advised my friend (for he was one) to run his boat into the mud between two tier of shipping. He did so--I jumped out of the boat, and he followed me--I lost both my shoes in the mud, and had no time to step again, before the boat in search of us was close in shore. We then agreed to lay down close to the mud. The boat struck the shore, and one of the people said, "Cockswain, where is that other boat gone to?" Luckily for us, it was the dark of the morning, and they could not perceive us. When they found that we were not to be seen, they said, "d--n them, let them go; pull away my lads," and went down the river, leaving us to help each other out of the mud--for the tide had got up to me. He having long boots on, did not mind it so much, and helped me out. As soon as we reached the wharf, we went to a tavern to wash ourselves, the landlord of which

--57--

said to my companion, "Tom, where have you been, that you are so full of mud?" He said, "this man has led me a fine jaunt this morning, from the Gravesend boat," and then told him the particulars, pretty much as I have related it. I then asked the boatman what I had to pay; but he refused to take anything until I told him where I came from, and why I had hurried him so, which I promised to do, on the condition that he should keep it secret. Says he, "you have run away from a man-of-war, and if you have, you are welcome to the pay; I was yesterday a man-of-war's-man, but a landsman to-day; I have been on board his majesty's ships, and I know how to pity those that are there."--Our conversation ended here, and I went out to the pump, to wash myself. I treated the boatman, and went down to the widow Bell's, where I found Capt. Cushing, who said to me, "you have come in good time, to help us get our goods in, for I lost all my men last night, by the press-gang, except my first mate, and one man who jumped into the ship's hold, and broke his leg.

I then went on board his ship (the Nonpareil of Boston) and went to work. Our captain had to hire men from the shore to help in with the cargo, until he could get a crew, which was finally made up of men who had been hiding themselves from the press-gang. After getting our cargo and passengers on board, we set sail, on the 2d Oct. 1787, for Boston. On running down the Channel, and abreast of Start Point, the wind shifted, and we had to

--58--

put away for Cowes, back of the Isle of Wight, where the passengers went on shore. We waited there a few days, when the wind was fair, and made sail; but had got no further than the Start, when the wind took us back again, and we had to put away for Cowes. The third day after the wind seemed fair, took the passengers on board, and reached the Start once more, but the wind made us put back, and run into Cowes again, where the passengers went on shore. In getting into the boat, Mrs. Sharp, (wife of Mr. Sharp, merchant, of Boston) said to Capt. Cushing, "if the wind is fair again, you may go out, and we will stay until you come back. About one o'clock at night, the wind was fair, when we sent a boat on shore for them, but they would not come. We weighed anchor, and fired three guns as a signal for sailing--but no boat appeared--and after waiting an hour for them, we run out to sea. The wind breezing up, we went past Start point at a rate of 8 knots an hour, with all sail set. The people left behind were Mr. Sharp, his wife, brother, and two sisters, neither of whom took any clothing with them.

In 11 days we made soundings on the outer Bank of Newfoundland. In the night of the 12th day, the wind came round to the northward, and blew so hard we had to put away before it, and take in all sail, except the goose-wing of the foresail. The wind continued blowing so hard for eight days, when it became calm, and we found ourselves in the latitude

--59--

of the Western Islands, and within a day's sail of Madeira. Afterwards the wind sprung up at the southeast, with moderate weather for some days.

One of our passengers, whom we had taken in in London, was taken down with the small pox, of which he had very bad symptoms--and died in six days after he was taken. In a day or two after, the first mate broke out--and the next day a boy, belonging to Capt. M'Clure, of Portsmouth, N. H. Three days after, a man belonging to Cambridge, Mass. had it very violently, and died in a few days; but the mate and boy got well.

We run to the westward for seven days, when the wind shifted to the northward again, and blew so hard as to make us put the ship away again. It continued to blow for six days, and then shifted to the southwest, which once more brought us on our own coast. We laid our courses for several days, when the wind shifted round to the westward for 13 days, with moderate weather, during all which time we had to beat off and on, and lost ground. The wind then shifting to the southward, we run into the Gulph Stream, where we were kept for 14 days, with baffling winds, and raining very hard almost all the time--afterwards the wind came up to the southwest, and we had to run north with all the sail we could set, in order to get out of the Stream, which happened to be the case, for we made the land, which proved to be Cape Sable. We stood to the southward, with the wind at the northeast, and

--60--

made soundings on George's Banks, a few leagues from Cape Cod.

It being Christmas Day, Captain Cushing was determined to have fresh fish for dinner. We threw out two or three lines, and caught four fish, which gave us a dainty dinner, it being nearly two months since we had any thing fresh to eat.

The wind continued fair for three days, when it shifted to the northwest, and blew so hard that we had to lay too for 26 hours; after that it abated, so that we were able to croud more sail, and beat to windward for two days, when it again shifted to the eastward, and clouded up, which made us expect a snow storm, but we happily found it to the contrary, although we had a little snow during the night, and in the morning the wind hauled round to the northward. About 8 o'clock next morning I went aloft to look around, (and anxious to see my native land once more) the Captain told me to keep a good look out to the windward. It not being very cold at that time, I stood at the fore top mast head until 2 o'clock, when looking very steadily over the weather bow, I thought that I saw land. I waited full one hour in the hope of proving it, when the clouds began to break away, when I realized what I before thought I had seen. In a few minutes I plainly discovered Cape Ann, which I immediately sung out. Captain Cushing told me that I was making fun of them--but I told him no. "How does it bear from us," said he; to which I said, "on the weather bow." I went down

-61---

on deck--Captain M'Clure insisted that we should not make the land before the next morning, and I offered to bett that we should; when he staked five dollars that we should not, which I agreed to. I then went down to dinner, where I had not been 15 minutes before a man on the forecastle cried out, "land on the weather bow," when I went on deck. Our captain said, "I am glad you have won your bett, for we shall be in Boston by four o'clock in the morning." I told him if I could, I would willingly give it up. The wind kept hauling to the N. and W. so fast, that by 10 o'clock that night we could not lay our course; and it began to blow so that we despaired of getting into the bay that night. In about two hours the wind got father to the northward, and with the help of the tide, we reached off Cohasset rocks, and fired a gun, as a signal for a pilot to come on board. The tide being against us, and the wind varying two points to the westward, we were obliged to come to an anchor off the rocks, where we lay all night, with handspikes in our hands, to knock off the ice as it gathered on the bows. By day light the wind shifted round to the southeast, when we weighed anchor, and run into Boston, and about 4 o'clock that afternoon we came to anchor opposite Long Wharf, on the 30th of December, 1787, after having been absent from my native town eight years, six months, and 17 days.

APPENDIX

[IN order to give the reader a more brief account of the different proceedings in the British navy, I have thought it best to add the following papers, for the information of my friends and fellow citizens.]

The author's advice to those of his countrymen, who should happen to be forced on board of any on the ships of his Britannic majesty.

My Friends, after the officer has taken your name, country, size, age, &c. down on the books, you are sent to the steward, who will then put you in a mess, and will tell you to go about the ship and find a messmate. Now is your time to avoid trouble. In the first place, inquire if any of your countrymen are on board, with whom you can mess. If not, endeavor to find one man, (and only one) that is willing to mess with you; for as sure as you go into a mess that has either 4, 6, 8, 10, or 12 in the mess, the time will come when you will wish you had not joined them; as you may be sure of having disputes when the gin begins to operate. If they fall to fighting, endeavor to avoid taking another's part, and thereby get yourself into a scrape--for if you beat one, another will challenge you; and if you chance to beat them all, it is nothing to boast of. It would be a wonder if you should come off without two black eyes, a bloody nose, your face bruised, and your ribs broken; and to finish the scene, the master at arms comes up and takes you by the collar, drags you to

--63--

the quarter deck to the officer, who orders you to be put in irons. The next day, the commanding officer orders you to be taken out of irons, brought on the main deck, and tied up to the gangway, where you receive a dozen lashes on your bare back with the cat-o'-nine-tails. Your misfortunes would put me in mind of the old proverb--

"Keep within compass, and you will be sure

To avoid many troubles which others endure."

Therefore, to avoid all those troubles, do as I have done. When I found them coming on, I left my company, and went into one of the tops, under the half deck, on the forecastle, down to the haul-up deck, or some other place, to get out of the way of such broils and confusion; and by your doing so, my friends, you will stand a good chance of receiving favors from your officers, as well as your ship's crew, which is the greatest ease of mind you can expect, until an opportunity offers when you may make your escape to your native country, and finally get clear of these dens of horror, cruelty, confusion, and continual uproar.

[I cannot here conclude without giving a few more words of advice to my countrymen who may have the misfortune to be impressed into the British Service.]

My friends, when you are taken on board a ship, you are measured for your height, and the colour of your hair and eyes taken. The lieutenant asks your name; the quarter master

--64--

calls the captain's clerk to put your name down on the ship's books, when you are sent down to the steward, to be put into a mess; the boatswain takes you to his yeoman, to get a hammock, when the master's mate measures a birth for you between decks. You are then put in some station, either on the forecastle, waist, afterguard, or some of the tops. Every Sunday the lieutenant reads the laws and rules to the crew.

My advice to you is, to avoid drinking, for it is the cause of all the troubles you meet with. If you get intoxicated, and fight with one of your own class, you are put in irons one night, and the next day are brought on deck, tied up to the gangway, and the boatswain's mate gives you a dozen lashes. If you strike a midshipman, you are put in irons one night, and receive four dozen the next day. If you strike an admiral, a commodore, captain, or lieutenant, you are tried by court martial, and sentenced to be hung up at the yard arm, or be flogged through the fleet. You have a right to speak in your behalf, and chuse whether you will be hung or flogged. On the morning of your execution, a yellow flag is hoisted at the fore-top-mast-head, as a signal, and a bow gun is fired, to inform the fleet, who lower their colours at half mast.

HANGING AT THE YARD-ARM.

If you prefer being hung, a day is appointed for your execution--the master at arms comes

--65--

down and knocks off your irons, and takes you up on the quarter deck, and from thence to the forecastle, where you stand until the captain of the forecastle goes on the end of the fore yard, and reves a rope through the block prepared for the purpose. One end of the rope is sent down, in order to put round your neck; the other end is run in under the fore yard, and reved through a block under the fore-top, and let down by the fore mast to the forecastle, and from thence to the ship's waist. The boatswain calls all hands on deck. The master at arms says to you, "go up on the cat-head," and ties the end of the rope fast round your neck, and says to the people, "set tort, men," when every man and boy on board, takes hold of the fall. The chaplain then comes up to the forecastle, and makes a short prayer--after which the master at arms turns to you, and says, "You are to be hung by the neck under the yard, until you are dead, dead, dead; and may the Lord have mercy on your soul;" then orders the people to run you up, and you are run up until your head touches the yard, when he takes the rope, and belays it, and thus you hang about half an hour. The boats are all hoisted out, in order to take you to the grave. The long boat is brought along side, with your coffin in it; when the master at arms takes off the lid, and you are lowered down into it; he then cuts the rope, leaving the knot on your neck; your clothes are all kept on, and your hat put on your face, when the lid is nailed down. The boats

--66--

are all made fast to each other, in a range, the captain's barge ahead, then the lieutenant's pinnace, the black cutter, the blue cutter, the yellow cutter, and the red cutter follow, which are made fast to the long boat, which has your body: these all go to low water mark, when four men jump out into the mud, and dig a hole three feet deep, in which you are deposited, for the next tide to roll over you.

FLOGGING THROUGH THE FLEET.

If you choose to be flogged through the fleet, the day is appointed, when you go into the long boat with the master at arms, where you are tied up by your hands to a machine made for the purpose. The boatswain's mate comes down and gives you fifty lashes with a cat-o'-nine-tails. The lieutenant orders all the boats belonging to your ship to be ranged as before, to tow you to the next ship, the boatswain's mate of which comes down and gives you fifty lashes more. In this manner you are carried from ship to ship, until you get the number of lashes imposed upon you--(during this, the drummer beats the dead march, and the bell strikes half-minute strokes.) If you live through it, you are taken to your ship, your back washed with brine, and cured as soon as possible--but if you die before you receive the complement, you are taken to every ship, and get every lash the Court Marshall ordered. Finally, you are put into your coffin, carried to low water mark, and there deposited.

--67--

On the 28th Dec. 1784, while we were laying in Plymouth sound, with a number of other ships, waiting orders, a man belonging to the Queen, of 98 guns, struck his first lieutenant, on the nose with his fist, which occasioned two black eyes. The man was tried by a court martial, and sentenced to receive 800 lashes. The day he was punished, after he had been flogged along side 13 ships, he was bro't to ours. The blanket was taken off his shoulders by our master at arms, when I observed his head hung back. Our captain ordered the doctor to feel his pulse, and found that the man was dead. Our boatswain's mate was then told to give him fifty lashes; "but," says the Captain, "lay them lightly on his back." He might as well have said put them lightly on his bones, for I could not see any flesh on him, from his neck to his waist. After this he was carried to two other ships, and received fifty lashes at each, and then carried to low water mark, and there buried in the mud.

RUNNING THE GAUNTLET.

IF you are caught in the act of stealing, you are put into irons, and there kept, to wait the pleasure of your officers. They generally sentence you to run the gauntlet, which is done as follows: you are brought upon deck the boatswain pipes all hands, and orders his yeoman to bring up a quantity of tarred rope yarns, of which every man is ordered to make a nettle by twisting three yarns together and making

-68---

three knots at one end. The men are then ordered to stand in two ranks round the deck, at five feet distance, and face each other. You are told to strip to your trowsers and get in between the ranks. The master at arms walks before you, with a sword under his arms, the point towards you, to prevent your running forward--and two corporals walk behind, with swords in their hands, to keep you from running back. The boatswain starts you by a stroke on the back with the cat-o'-nine-tails--every man then strikes you as hard and fast as he can. You have to go round the deck three times in this manner, in common time. When you reach the break of the forecastle the boatswain's first mate gives you a cut with his cat-o'-nine-tails; the second another, and the third another, when you get round to the boatswain again, he gives you another, and so on, until you have been round the deck three times. It is in vain for you to cry, scream, jump, roll, for you must grin and bear it, as none will pity you. Finally, you look like a piece of raw beef from your neck to the waist of your trowsers. You are taken down to the cockpit, and there have salt brine rubbed on your back, by the doctor's mate. If you should be so fortunate as to get over this, you must go to work again.

A SPECIMEN OF THE BRITISH OFFICERS.

While the Irresistible lay off Chatham, I took particular note of one instance of barbarity.

--69--

One morning the hands were piped on deck, and ordered to wash the decks, as usual. The men being ordered aft to haul the Holy-Stone. Charles Mansfield, our third lieutenant, came on deck, and called the list over. Two men, belonging to the main-top, were missing; he told the boatswain's mate to send them aft. On going to the quarter deck, the lieutenant says, "you d--d rascals, why were you not on deck before," and not waiting for an answer, sings out, "main deck there! come aft, boatswain's mates, take these fellows, and give them a d--d hiding." They collared each of them, and beat them with a suple-jack until they were so tired that they could do it no longer. The lieutenant then bid the men to go to their duty--but as they grumbled a little when they went to the gangway, they were called back again, and the boatswain and his other mate were ordered on the quarter-deck, when the lieutenant said, "take these fellows and give them another hiding, for grumbling." They took hold of them, and beat them so unmercifully, that the men begged for mercy, and requested to be tried by a court martial. "I'll court martial you," said he, "call the master at arms, and tell him to put these rascals in irons," who took the men down between decks, and put them both in feet-cuffs, in which situation they were kept three days. On the fourth morning they were taken up on deck; Mr. Westcott, the first lieutenant, said, "men, you may go to your duty again;" they took off their hats, and thanked him, and went below.
